snippet: According to statistics compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, 72 police officers were killed in 2011, a 25 percent increase from the previous year and 75 percent rise from 2008.
abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation statistics show that 72 police officers were killed by perpetrators in 2011, 25 percent increase from 2010 and 75 percent increase from 2008; some law enforcement officials believe that techniques pioneered by New York City Police Department and adopted by other departments are to blame because they put officers at greater risk by encouraging them to conduct more street stops and to confront suspects who seem likely to be armed; others link rise in violence to the tough economy.

byline.original: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
byline.contributor: Michael S. Schmidt reported from Washington, and Joseph Goldstein from New York. John H. Cushman Jr. contributed reporting from Washington.
